questions.question: Define F-centres. How does their presence affect the color of alkali halides?
questions.correctAnswer: F-centres are vacancies in the crystal lattice occupied by electrons; their presence imparts color to alkali halides.
questions.solution: F-centres (Farbe centres, from German for 'colour') are anion vacancies in a crystal lattice that are occupied by electrons to maintain electrical neutrality. They are created when an alkali halide (e.g., NaCl) is heated in an atmosphere of its constituent alkali metal vapour (e.g., Na vapour). Extra Na atoms ionise; Na⁺ ions occupy lattice sites and the released electrons occupy anion vacancies. The trapped electrons can absorb visible light and get excited to higher energy levels. The complementary colour of the absorbed light is emitted/transmitted, imparting colour to the crystal. E.g., NaCl heated in Na vapour → yellow colour; KCl heated in K vapour → violet colour.

questions.question: Why does increasing the temperature generally increase the rate of a chemical reaction?
questions.correctAnswer: Increase in temperature raises kinetic energy of molecules, leading to more effective collisions and thus higher reaction rate.
questions.solution: Increasing temperature affects the reaction rate in two ways: 1. Increased kinetic energy: Molecules move faster, leading to a greater frequency of collisions per unit time. 2. More molecules exceed activation energy: As temperature rises, a larger fraction of molecules possess energy equal to or greater than the activation energy (Eₐ), as described by the Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution. These molecules can undergo effective (fruitful) collisions. According to the Arrhenius equation: $$k = A \cdot e^{-E_a/RT}$$ As $T$ increases, $e^{-E_a/RT}$ increases, so $k$ (rate constant) increases, and hence the reaction rate increases. A rule of thumb: For every 10°C rise in temperature, the rate approximately doubles.

questions.question: State Raoult's law for ideal solutions. Give one example of an ideal solution.
questions.correctAnswer: Raoult's law states that the partial vapour pressure of each component in an ideal solution is proportional to its mole fraction; example: benzene and toluene solution.
questions.solution: Raoult's Law: For an ideal solution containing two volatile components A and B, the partial vapour pressure of each component is directly proportional to its mole fraction in the solution: $$p_A = p_A^\circ \cdot x_A \quad \text{and} \quad p_B = p_B^\circ \cdot x_B$$ where $p_A^\circ$ and $p_B^\circ$ are the vapour pressures of pure A and B respectively, and $x_A$, $x_B$ are their mole fractions. The total vapour pressure: $$p_{\text{total}} = p_A + p_B = p_A^\circ x_A + p_B^\circ x_B$$ Example of an ideal solution: A solution of benzene and toluene (both are non-polar, similar in size and intermolecular forces, obey Raoult's law over the entire range of composition).

questions.question:
Write the cell reaction and calculate the EMF of the following cell at 25°C:

$$\text{Zn(s)}|\text{Zn}^{2+}(1\ \text{M})||\text{Cu}^{2+}(1\ \text{M})|\text{Cu(s)}$$
questions.correctAnswer: $\text{Zn(s)} + \text{Cu}^{2+}\text{(aq)} \rightarrow \text{Zn}^{2+}\text{(aq)} + \text{Cu(s)}$; EMF ≈ 1.10 V.
questions.solution: Cell Reaction: At anode (oxidation): $\text{Zn(s)} \rightarrow \text{Zn}^{2+}\text{(aq)} + 2e^-$. At cathode (reduction): $\text{Cu}^{2+}\text{(aq)} + 2e^- \rightarrow \text{Cu(s)}$. Overall: $\text{Zn(s)} + \text{Cu}^{2+}\text{(aq)} \rightarrow \text{Zn}^{2+}\text{(aq)} + \text{Cu(s)}$. EMF Calculation using standard electrode potentials: $$E^\circ_{\text{Cu}^{2+}/\text{Cu}} = +0.34\ \text{V}, \quad E^\circ_{\text{Zn}^{2+}/\text{Zn}} = -0.76\ \text{V}$$ $$E^\circ_{\text{cell}} = E^\circ_{\text{cathode}} - E^\circ_{\text{anode}} = +0.34 - (-0.76) = +1.10\ \text{V}$$ Since both concentrations are 1 M (standard conditions), by Nernst equation the EMF = $E^\circ_{\text{cell}}$ = 1.10 V.

questions.question: Explain why transition metals form colored compounds.
questions.correctAnswer: Transition metals form colored compounds due to d–d electron transitions when exposed to light.
questions.solution: Transition metals have partially filled d-orbitals. In the presence of ligands, the d-orbitals split into two sets of different energy levels (crystal field splitting): $e_g$ and $t_{2g}$ (in an octahedral field). When visible light falls on a transition metal compound, electrons in the lower energy d-orbitals absorb photons of specific wavelength and are excited to higher energy d-orbitals — this is called a d–d transition. The complementary colour of the absorbed light is transmitted/reflected, giving the compound its characteristic colour. Example: $[\text{Cu(H}_2\text{O)}_6]^{2+}$ absorbs red light and appears blue. Note: Zn²⁺ compounds are colourless because Zn²⁺ has a completely filled d¹⁰ configuration — no d–d transitions possible.

questions.question: Give the equation for the preparation of acetaldehyde from ethanol. Name the catalyst used.
questions.correctAnswer: $\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH} + [\text{O}] \rightarrow \text{CH}_3\text{CHO} + \text{H}_2\text{O}$; catalyst: acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ or PCC.
questions.solution: Acetaldehyde (ethanal) is prepared by the oxidation of ethanol (primary alcohol): $$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH} \xrightarrow{[\text{O}]} \text{CH}_3\text{CHO} + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$ Catalysts/Oxidising agents used: Acidified potassium dichromate (K₂Cr₂O₇/H₂SO₄) or Pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC) — a mild oxidising agent that stops at the aldehyde stage. The reaction involves removal of two hydrogen atoms (oxidation) from ethanol to form ethanal. Care must be taken to avoid over-oxidation to acetic acid (ethanoic acid).

questions.question: Differentiate between thermoplastic and thermosetting polymers with suitable examples.
questions.correctAnswer: Thermoplastics soften on heating and can be reshaped; e.g. PVC. Thermosetting polymers harden permanently after moulding; e.g. Bakelite.
questions.solution: Thermoplastic Polymers: Soften on heating; can be remoulded and reshaped. Have linear or slightly branched chains held by weak van der Waals forces. Can be recycled. Soluble in suitable solvents. Examples: Polyethylene, PVC, Polystyrene, Nylon. Thermosetting Polymers: Harden permanently on heating; cannot be reshaped. Have extensively cross-linked 3D network structure. Cannot be recycled. Insoluble in most solvents. Examples: Bakelite, Melamine, Urea-formaldehyde resin.

questions.question: How does the presence of non-volatile solute affect the boiling point of a solvent? Name this phenomenon.
questions.correctAnswer: Boiling point of solvent increases due to non-volatile solute; this is called elevation of boiling point.
questions.solution: When a non-volatile solute is dissolved in a solvent, the vapour pressure of the solvent decreases (as given by Raoult's law, since $x_{\text{solvent}} < 1$). A liquid boils when its vapour pressure equals the atmospheric pressure. Since the vapour pressure is lowered, a higher temperature is needed to reach atmospheric pressure. Therefore, the boiling point of the solution is higher than that of the pure solvent. This phenomenon is called: Elevation of Boiling Point (Ebullioscopy). The mathematical relation: $$\Delta T_b = K_b \cdot m$$ where $K_b$ is the ebullioscopic constant and $m$ is the molality of the solution.

questions.question: Although NH₃ has higher molar mass than PH₃, it has lower boiling point. Explain.
questions.correctAnswer: Note: The question statement contains an error. NH₃ actually has a HIGHER boiling point than PH₃ due to hydrogen bonding.
questions.solution: Correct explanation: NH₃ (boiling point: –33°C) forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds (N–H···N) due to the high electronegativity of nitrogen and the presence of a lone pair. This requires significantly more energy to overcome. PH₃ (boiling point: –87°C) cannot form hydrogen bonds because phosphorus is not electronegative enough. It is held together only by weak van der Waals forces. Despite having a higher molar mass (and thus stronger London dispersion forces), PH₃ has a lower boiling point than NH₃ because hydrogen bonding in NH₃ is a much stronger intermolecular force. Therefore: NH₃ has a higher boiling point than PH₃, not lower.

questions.question: Write the relation between Gibbs energy and cell potential for an electrochemical cell.
questions.correctAnswer: $\Delta G = -nFE_{\text{cell}}$ relates Gibbs energy and cell potential.
questions.solution: The relationship between Gibbs free energy ($\Delta G$) and cell potential ($E_{\text{cell}}$) is: $$\boxed{\Delta G = -nFE_{\text{cell}}}$$ Where: $\Delta G$ = Gibbs free energy change (in joules), $n$ = number of moles of electrons transferred in the cell reaction, $F$ = Faraday's constant ($= 96485\ \text{C mol}^{-1} \approx 96500\ \text{C mol}^{-1}$), $E_{\text{cell}}$ = EMF of the cell (in volts). For standard conditions: $$\Delta G^\circ = -nFE^\circ_{\text{cell}}$$ If $E_{\text{cell}} > 0$, then $\Delta G < 0$ → reaction is spontaneous. If $E_{\text{cell}} < 0$, then $\Delta G > 0$ → reaction is non-spontaneous.

questions.question: The rate equation for a reaction is: $\text{rate} = k[\text{A}]^1[\text{B}]^2$. What is the order of the reaction?
questions.correctAnswer: Order of the reaction is $1 + 2 = 3$.
questions.solution: Given rate law: $\text{rate} = k[\text{A}]^1[\text{B}]^2$. Order with respect to A = 1. Order with respect to B = 2. Overall order = sum of all exponents = $1 + 2 = 3$. The reaction is a third-order reaction. The unit of rate constant $k$ for a third-order reaction is $\text{L}^2\ \text{mol}^{-2}\ \text{s}^{-1}$.

questions.question: Write one example each of synthetic and natural polymers.
questions.correctAnswer: Synthetic polymer: Nylon; Natural polymer: Cellulose.
questions.solution: Synthetic Polymer: A polymer that is man-made/artificially synthesised. Example: Nylon-6,6 — formed by condensation polymerisation of hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid. Used in making fabrics, ropes, and gears. Natural Polymer: A polymer that occurs naturally in living organisms. Example: Cellulose — a polysaccharide made of β-D-glucose units linked by 1,4-glycosidic bonds. Forms the cell walls of plants. Other examples — Synthetic: Polythene, PVC, Bakelite, Terylene. Natural: Starch, Natural rubber (polyisoprene), Proteins, Nucleic acids.

questions.question: Give the IUPAC name for $(\text{CH}_3)_3\text{CNH}_2$.
questions.correctAnswer: 2-Amino-2-methylpropane (or 2-methylpropan-2-amine).
questions.solution: Structure of $(\text{CH}_3)_3\text{CNH}_2$: Central carbon bonded to three –CH₃ groups and one –NH₂ group. The compound is tert-butylamine. Parent chain: propane (3C chain). At C-2: methyl group and amino group. IUPAC Name: 2-methylpropan-2-amine (also accepted: 2-amino-2-methylpropane). The –NH₂ is on the central carbon of a propane chain with a methyl substituent at the same carbon.

questions.question: Explain the difference between competitive and non-competitive enzyme inhibition.
questions.correctAnswer: Competitive inhibition: inhibitor competes with substrate for active site; non-competitive inhibition: inhibitor binds elsewhere, changing enzyme shape.
questions.solution: Competitive Inhibition: Inhibitor binds to the active site of the enzyme, competing with the substrate for the same active site. Can be overcome by increasing substrate concentration. Vmax remains the same; apparent Km increases. Example: Malonate inhibiting succinate dehydrogenase. Non-Competitive Inhibition: Inhibitor binds to an allosteric site (different from active site), changing the conformation of the enzyme and reducing its catalytic activity. Cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration. Vmax decreases; Km remains unchanged. Example: Heavy metal ions inhibiting enzymes.

questions.question: Why is potassium permanganate considered a self-indicator in redox titrations?
questions.correctAnswer: KMnO₄ acts as its own indicator by changing colour as it reacts and is reduced in redox titrations.
questions.solution: KMnO₄ (potassium permanganate) is an intensely purple/violet coloured compound. In acidic medium, it acts as a strong oxidising agent and gets reduced to Mn²⁺ (which is nearly colourless in dilute solution): $$\text{MnO}_4^- + 8\text{H}^+ + 5e^- \rightarrow \text{Mn}^{2+} + 4\text{H}_2\text{O}$$ During the titration, as long as the reducing agent (e.g., Fe²⁺, oxalic acid) is present, the purple colour of KMnO₄ is immediately discharged (becomes colourless). At the end point, when the reducing agent is completely consumed, the addition of even one extra drop of KMnO₄ imparts a permanent pale pink/violet colour to the solution. Since KMnO₄ itself signals the end point through its colour change, no separate indicator is needed — it is called a self-indicator.
questions.topic: d and f Block Elements / Electrochemistry

questions.question: Write two differences between lyophilic and lyophobic sols.
questions.correctAnswer: Lyophilic sols are easily prepared and reversible; lyophobic sols are not, and irreversible.
questions.solution: Lyophilic Sols ('Solvent-loving'): Dispersed phase has strong affinity for the dispersion medium. Easily prepared by simply dissolving/dispersing. More stable; not easily coagulated. Reversible — can be converted back to sol from precipitate. Examples: Starch, gelatin, gum, protein sols. Lyophobic Sols ('Solvent-hating'): Dispersed phase has little or no affinity for the dispersion medium. Prepared by special methods (arc method, peptisation); not formed spontaneously. Less stable; easily coagulated by adding electrolytes. Irreversible — once coagulated, cannot be easily redispersed. Examples: Gold sol, As₂S₃ sol, Fe(OH)₃ sol.

questions.question: State the function of DNA in the synthesis of proteins.
questions.correctAnswer: DNA carries genetic information and serves as a template for protein synthesis via transcription and translation.
questions.solution: DNA plays a central role in protein synthesis through two main processes: 1. Transcription: The double-stranded DNA unwinds and one strand serves as a template for the synthesis of messenger RNA (mRNA) by RNA polymerase. The mRNA sequence is complementary to the DNA template strand. 2. Translation: The mRNA moves to the ribosome, where it is read in codons (triplets of nucleotide bases). Transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules carry specific amino acids to the ribosome and match anticodons with mRNA codons. Amino acids are joined by peptide bonds to form the polypeptide chain (protein). In summary: DNA → (Transcription) → mRNA → (Translation) → Protein. The sequence of bases in DNA determines the sequence of amino acids in the protein, following the central dogma of molecular biology.

questions.question: Draw the structure of 2,4-dinitrophenol.
questions.correctAnswer: Structure shows benzene ring with –OH at 1-position and –NO₂ at 2- and 4-positions.
questions.solution: 2,4-Dinitrophenol has: –OH at C-1, –NO₂ at C-2 (ortho), –NO₂ at C-4 (para). The compound has a benzene ring with hydroxyl group at position 1, nitro group at position 2 (adjacent/ortho), and nitro group at position 4 (para). It is a yellow crystalline solid and is more acidic than phenol due to the electron-withdrawing –NO₂ groups.

questions.question: What are semiconductors? Give one example.
questions.correctAnswer: Semiconductors have conductivity between metals and insulators; e.g. silicon.
questions.solution: Semiconductors are substances whose electrical conductivity lies between that of conductors (metals) and insulators. Their conductivity typically ranges from $10^{-6}$ to $10^4\ \text{S m}^{-1}$. Characteristics: Have a small band gap between the valence band and the conduction band (typically 0.1–3 eV). At absolute zero, they behave as insulators. At higher temperatures, some electrons gain enough energy to jump to the conduction band, increasing conductivity. Conductivity increases with temperature (unlike metals). Types: Intrinsic semiconductors — Pure semiconductors (e.g., Si, Ge). Extrinsic semiconductors — Doped with impurities to enhance conductivity (n-type with group 15 elements; p-type with group 13 elements). Example: Silicon (Si) — used extensively in solar cells, transistors, and integrated circuits.

questions.question: Arrange the following in increasing order of bond length: N₂, O₂, F₂
questions.correctAnswer: $\text{N}_2 < \text{O}_2 < \text{F}_2$
questions.solution: Bond length is inversely related to bond order (higher bond order = shorter, stronger bond). N₂: Bond Order = 3 (triple bond), Bond Length = 110 pm. O₂: Bond Order = 2 (double bond), Bond Length = 121 pm. F₂: Bond Order = 1 (single bond), Bond Length = 144 pm. Increasing order of bond length: $\text{N}_2 < \text{O}_2 < \text{F}_2$. As bond order decreases from N₂ (3) to O₂ (2) to F₂ (1), the bond length increases.

questions.question:
Calculate the potential of the Iron electrode in which the concentration of Fe²⁺ ion is 0.01 M.

$$\left(E°_{\text{Fe}^{2+}/\text{Fe}} = -0.45\ \text{V at } 298\ \text{K}\right) \quad \text{Given: } \log_{10} 10 = 1$$
questions.solution: For the iron electrode half-reaction: $$\text{Fe}^{2+} + 2e^- \rightarrow \text{Fe}$$ Using the Nernst equation: $$E = E° - \frac{0.0591}{n} \log \frac{[\text{reduced form}]}{[\text{oxidised form}]}$$ Since Fe is a solid, its activity = 1. Thus: $$E_{\text{Fe}^{2+}/\text{Fe}} = E°_{\text{Fe}^{2+}/\text{Fe}} - \frac{0.0591}{2} \log \frac{1}{[\text{Fe}^{2+}]}$$ $$E = -0.45 - \frac{0.0591}{2} \log \frac{1}{0.01}$$ $$\log\left(\frac{1}{0.01}\right) = \log 100 = 2$$ $$E = -0.45 - \frac{0.0591}{2} \times 2$$ $$E = -0.45 - 0.0591$$ $$E = -0.5091\ \text{V}$$

questions.question: Define molecularity of the reaction. State any one condition in which a bimolecular reaction may be kinetically of first order.
questions.correctAnswer: Molecularity is the number of reacting species that must collide simultaneously in a single elementary step. A bimolecular reaction is kinetically first order when one reactant is in large excess (pseudo-first-order conditions).
questions.solution:
Molecularity: The number of reacting species (atoms, ions, or molecules) that must collide simultaneously in a single elementary step to bring about that reaction is called the molecularity of the reaction.

Condition for first-order kinetics in a bimolecular reaction: If one of the two reactants is present in a very large excess compared to the other, its concentration remains effectively constant throughout the reaction. The reaction then appears to depend only on the concentration of the reactant present in smaller quantity, making it a pseudo-first-order reaction.

For example, the acid hydrolysis of an ester in excess water: $$\text{CH}_3\text{COOC}_2\text{H}_5 + \text{H}_2\text{O} \xrightarrow{\text{H}^+} \text{CH}_3\text{COOH} + \text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{OH}$$ Although bimolecular, it follows first-order kinetics because water is in large excess.

questions.question:
What happens when D-glucose is treated with the following reagents?

(a) HI
(b) Conc. HNO₃
questions.correctAnswer: (a) n-hexane is formed; (b) Saccharic acid (glucaric acid) is formed.
questions.solution:
(a) Treatment with HI: When D-glucose is treated with HI (hydroiodic acid), all the –OH groups are reduced. The product is n-hexane: $$\text{D-glucose} \xrightarrow{\text{HI}} \text{n-hexane (CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_3\text{)}$$ This confirms that glucose has a straight (unbranched) six-carbon chain.

(b) Treatment with Conc. HNO₃: When D-glucose is treated with concentrated HNO₃, the aldehyde group (–CHO) at C-1 and the primary alcohol group (–CH₂OH) at C-6 are both oxidised to –COOH groups, yielding saccharic acid (glucaric acid), a dicarboxylic acid: $$\text{D-glucose} \xrightarrow{\text{Conc. HNO}_3} \text{Saccharic acid (HOOC–(CHOH)}_4\text{–COOH)}$$

questions.question:
Draw the structures of major monohalo products in each of the following reactions:

(i) Styrene (Ph–CH=CH₂) + HBr →
(ii) Cyclohexane + Br₂ $\xrightarrow{\text{UV light}}$
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Ph–CHBr–CH₃ (1-bromo-1-phenylethane); (ii) Bromocyclohexane
questions.solution:
(i) Ph–CH=CH₂ + HBr → Addition of HBr to styrene follows Markovnikov's rule: H adds to the terminal CH₂ (less substituted carbon), and Br adds to the benzylic carbon (more substituted, forms a more stable benzylic carbocation): $$\text{Ph–CH=CH}_2 + \text{HBr} \rightarrow \text{Ph–CHBr–CH}_3$$ Major product: 1-bromo-1-phenylethane (PhCHBr–CH₃)

(ii) Cyclohexane + Br₂ under UV light: Under UV light, free radical halogenation occurs. All hydrogens in cyclohexane are equivalent, so only one monobromo product is possible. Major product: Bromocyclohexane (six-membered cyclohexane ring with one Br substituent).

alternativeQuestion.question:
Give reasons for the following:

(i) Grignard reagent should be prepared under anhydrous conditions.
(ii) Alkyl halides give alcohol with aqueous KOH whereas in the presence of alcoholic KOH, alkenes are formed.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (i) Grignard reagents react with water to give hydrocarbons, destroying the reagent. (ii) Aqueous KOH: OH⁻ acts as nucleophile giving alcohol (SN2); Alcoholic KOH: OH⁻ acts as base causing elimination (E2) to give alkene.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Grignard reagents (RMgX) are highly reactive organometallic compounds. They react readily with water (or any protic source) to give the corresponding hydrocarbon and destroy the reagent: $$\text{RMgX} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{RH} + \text{Mg(OH)X}$$ To prevent this decomposition and preserve the Grignard reagent for use in organic synthesis, it must be prepared and handled under strictly anhydrous (water-free) conditions, typically using dry diethyl ether as solvent.

(ii) Aqueous KOH: The OH⁻ ion acts as a nucleophile and displaces the halide via an SN2 mechanism, forming an alcohol: $$\text{R–X} + \text{KOH}_{(\text{aq})} \rightarrow \text{R–OH} + \text{KX}$$ Alcoholic KOH: In alcoholic medium, OH⁻ acts as a base rather than a nucleophile. It abstracts a β-hydrogen from the alkyl halide, leading to elimination (E2 mechanism) and formation of an alkene: $$\text{R–CH}_2\text{–CH}_2\text{X} + \text{KOH}_{(\text{alc})} \rightarrow \text{R–CH=CH}_2 + \text{KX} + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$ The polarity of the medium (aqueous vs. alcoholic) determines whether substitution or elimination occurs.

questions.question:
Write the chemical equation when:

(a) Butan-2-one is treated with Zn(Hg) and conc. HCl.
(b) Two molecules of benzaldehyde are treated with conc. NaOH.
questions.correctAnswer: (a) Butane is formed via Clemmensen reduction. (b) Benzyl alcohol and sodium benzoate are formed via Cannizzaro reaction.
questions.solution:
(a) Clemmensen Reduction of Butan-2-one: Butan-2-one (methyl ethyl ketone) is reduced to butane using Zn(Hg)/conc. HCl (Clemmensen reduction): $$\text{CH}_3\text{COCH}_2\text{CH}_3 + 4[\text{H}] \xrightarrow{\text{Zn/Hg, HCl}} \text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_3 + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$

(b) Cannizzaro Reaction of Benzaldehyde: Two molecules of benzaldehyde (a non-enolisable aldehyde) undergo disproportionation in the presence of conc. NaOH. One molecule is oxidised to benzoic acid (as its sodium salt) and the other is reduced to benzyl alcohol: $$2\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{CHO} + \text{NaOH} \rightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{CH}_2\text{OH} + \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{COONa}$$

questions.question: What is Henry's law? Give one application of it.
questions.correctAnswer: Henry's law states that at constant temperature, the solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid: $p = K_H \cdot x$. Application: Used in the carbonated beverage industry — CO₂ is dissolved under high pressure; when the bottle is opened pressure decreases and CO₂ escapes causing effervescence.
questions.solution:
**Henry's Law:** Henry's law states that at constant temperature, the solubility (or the partial pressure) of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid. Mathematically:
$$p = K_H \cdot x$$
where $p$ is the partial pressure of the gas, $K_H$ is Henry's law constant, and $x$ is the mole fraction of the gas in the solution.

**Application:** Henry's law is used in the carbonated beverage industry. Carbon dioxide ($\text{CO}_2$) is dissolved in beverages under high pressure. When the bottle is opened, the pressure decreases, and $\text{CO}_2$ escapes from the solution, causing effervescence (fizzing). Other applications include:
- Understanding the condition of anoxia and altitude sickness (at high altitude, low partial pressure of O₂ leads to less O₂ dissolving in blood).
- Scuba diving (to understand the effect of high pressure on gas solubility in blood).

questions.question: (a) On diluting two electrolytes 'A' and 'B', the $\Lambda_m$ of 'A' increases 25 times while that of 'B' increases by 1.5 times. Which of the two electrolytes is strong? Justify your answer graphically.
questions.correctAnswer: 'B' is the strong electrolyte. Strong electrolytes show only a small increase in molar conductivity upon dilution (B increases only 1.5 times), whereas weak electrolytes show a large increase (A increases 25 times) because dilution promotes dissociation.
questions.solution:
'B' is the strong electrolyte.

**Explanation:** Strong electrolytes are already almost completely dissociated at moderate concentrations. Upon dilution, their molar conductivity increases only slightly (by a small amount) because the interionic interactions decrease. Weak electrolytes, on the other hand, show a dramatic increase in molar conductivity upon dilution because dilution promotes dissociation significantly.

Since the $\Lambda_m$ of 'A' increases 25 times (a very large increase) upon dilution, 'A' is a **weak electrolyte**. Since the $\Lambda_m$ of 'B' increases by only 1.5 times (a small increase), 'B' is the **strong electrolyte**.

[Diagram: A graph of $\Lambda_m$ vs $\sqrt{c}$ showing two curves — Curve B (strong electrolyte) is nearly linear with a small slope, starting from a high value and reaching $\Lambda_m^\circ$ with a small increase. Curve A (weak electrolyte) starts at a low value and rises steeply at low concentrations, showing a large increase in $\Lambda_m$ upon dilution. Both curves approach $\Lambda_m^\circ$ at infinite dilution.]

alternativeQuestion.question: (b) The electrical resistance of a column of $0.05\ \text{mol L}^{-1}$ NaOH solution of diameter 1 cm and length 50 cm is $5.55 \times 10^3\ \Omega$. Calculate the conductivity.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**Given:**
- Resistance, $R = 5.55 \times 10^3\ \Omega$
- Length, $l = 50\ \text{cm}$
- Diameter $= 1\ \text{cm}$, so radius $= 0.5\ \text{cm}$

**Cross-sectional area:**
$$A = \pi r^2 = \pi \times (0.5)^2 = 0.7854\ \text{cm}^2$$

**Conductivity** is given by:
$$\kappa = \frac{1}{R} \times \frac{l}{A}$$

$$\kappa = \frac{1}{5.55 \times 10^3} \times \frac{50}{0.7854}$$

$$\kappa = \frac{63.66}{5550}\ \text{S cm}^{-1}$$

$$\boxed{\kappa \approx 0.01147\ \text{S cm}^{-1}}$$

questions.question:
Complete the following equations:

(a) $2\text{MnO}_4^- + 5\text{NO}_2^- + 6\text{H}^+ \rightarrow$

(b) $\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6e^- \rightarrow$
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) $2\text{MnO}_4^- + 5\text{NO}_2^- + 6\text{H}^+ \rightarrow 2\text{Mn}^{2+} + 5\text{NO}_3^- + 3\text{H}_2\text{O}$

(b) $\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6e^- \rightarrow 2\text{Cr}^{3+} + 7\text{H}_2\text{O}$
questions.solution:
(a) Permanganate ($\text{MnO}_4^-$) acts as an oxidising agent in acidic medium, being reduced from Mn(+7) to Mn(+2). Nitrite ($\text{NO}_2^-$) is oxidised to nitrate ($\text{NO}_3^-$), with N going from +3 to +5. Balancing electrons: each $\text{MnO}_4^-$ gains 5 electrons, and each $\text{NO}_2^-$ loses 2 electrons. Using LCM: 2 $\text{MnO}_4^-$ gain 10 electrons and 5 $\text{NO}_2^-$ lose 10 electrons. Balancing H and O with H⁺ and H₂O:
$$2\text{MnO}_4^- + 5\text{NO}_2^- + 6\text{H}^+ \rightarrow 2\text{Mn}^{2+} + 5\text{NO}_3^- + 3\text{H}_2\text{O}$$

(b) Dichromate ion ($\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-}$) is reduced in acidic medium. Each Cr goes from +6 to +3, a gain of 3 electrons per Cr atom, so 6 electrons total for 2 Cr atoms. The 7 oxygen atoms combine with 14 H⁺ to form 7 H₂O molecules:
$$\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6e^- \rightarrow 2\text{Cr}^{3+} + 7\text{H}_2\text{O}$$

questions.question:
(a) Identify 'A' and 'B' in the following reactions:

$$\text{CH}_3-\underset{|}{\overset{}{\text{CH}}}-\text{CH}_3 \xrightarrow{\text{PCl}_5} \text{'A'} \xrightarrow{\text{AgCN}} \text{'B'}$$
$$\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \text{OH}$$

(b) Identify 'A' and 'B' in the following reactions:

$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{Cl} \xrightarrow{\text{KOH (ethanol)}} \text{'A'} \xrightarrow{\text{HBr}} \text{'B'}$$
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) A: $\text{CH}_3\text{CH(Cl)CH}_3$ (2-chloropropane); B: $\text{CH}_3\text{CH(CN)CH}_3$ (2-methylpropanenitrile)

(b) A: $\text{CH}_3\text{CH=CH}_2$ (Propene); B: $\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{Br}$ (1-bromopropane)
questions.solution:
(a)
- Step 1: 2-propanol reacts with $\text{PCl}_5$ to give 2-chloropropane (A) via substitution of the $-\text{OH}$ group by $-\text{Cl}$.
- Step 2: 2-chloropropane reacts with AgCN (which provides $\text{CN}^-$ as a nucleophile) to give 2-methylpropanenitrile (B) via an $S_N2$ reaction. AgCN reacts through carbon of CN⁻, giving a nitrile.

(b)
- Step 1: n-propyl chloride undergoes elimination (E2) with alcoholic KOH to give propene (A).
- Step 2: Propene reacts with HBr. B is $\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{CH}_2\text{Br}$ (1-bromopropane) formed under anti-Markovnikov (peroxide) conditions; under normal ionic conditions, Markovnikov product ($\text{CH}_3\text{CHBrCH}_3$) is expected.

questions.question:
(a) Account for the following:

(i) Phenol is a stronger acid than an alcohol.

(ii) The boiling point of alcohols decreases with increase in branching of the alkyl chain.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Phenol is a stronger acid because the phenoxide ion is stabilized by resonance with the benzene ring, unlike the alkoxide ion from alcohols. (ii) Increased branching creates a more compact spherical shape, reducing surface area and weakening London dispersion forces, thus lowering the boiling point.
questions.solution:
(i) Phenol is a stronger acid than alcohol because the phenoxide ion ($\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{O}^-$) formed after loss of a proton ($\text{H}^+$) is stabilized by resonance with the benzene ring. The negative charge on the oxygen is delocalized over the ring through resonance, making the phenoxide ion more stable. In contrast, the alkoxide ion ($\text{RO}^-$) formed from alcohols has no such resonance stabilization and is therefore less stable, making alcohols weaker acids. Greater stability of the conjugate base means greater acid strength, so phenol is a stronger acid than alcohols.

(ii) As branching in the alkyl chain increases, the shape of the molecule becomes more spherical and compact, which reduces the surface area available for intermolecular contact. Decreased surface area leads to weaker London dispersion forces (Van der Waals forces) between the molecules. Since less energy is required to overcome these weaker intermolecular forces, the boiling point decreases with increasing branching.

alternativeQuestion.question:
(b)
(i) Write the mechanism of the following reaction:

$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH} \xrightarrow{\text{H}^+,\ 443\text{ K}} \text{CH}_2{=}\text{CH}_2 + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$

(ii) Write the equation involved in Reimer-Tiemann reaction.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (i) Mechanism: Step 1 — Protonation of ethanol to form oxonium ion; Step 2 — Loss of water to form carbocation; Step 3 — Loss of proton to form ethene. (ii) $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{OH} + \text{CHCl}_3 + 3\text{NaOH} \rightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_4(\text{CHO})(\text{OH}) + 3\text{NaCl} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) The mechanism is an acid-catalysed dehydration (E1) proceeding in three steps:

**Step 1 — Protonation of ethanol:**
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH} + \text{H}^+ \rightarrow \text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\overset{+}{\text{OH}}_2$$
The oxygen of ethanol is protonated by the acid to form an oxonium ion.

**Step 2 — Formation of carbocation:**
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\overset{+}{\text{OH}}_2 \rightarrow \text{CH}_3\overset{+}{\text{CH}}_2 + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$
Water leaves as a good leaving group, generating a primary carbocation (ethyl carbocation).

**Step 3 — Loss of proton to form alkene:**
$$\text{CH}_3\overset{+}{\text{CH}}_2 \rightarrow \text{CH}_2{=}\text{CH}_2 + \text{H}^+$$
A proton is lost from the adjacent carbon, forming the double bond and regenerating the acid catalyst.

(ii) In the Reimer-Tiemann reaction, phenol reacts with chloroform ($\text{CHCl}_3$) in the presence of aqueous NaOH to give ortho-hydroxy benzaldehyde (salicylaldehyde) as the major product:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{OH} + \text{CHCl}_3 + 3\text{NaOH} \rightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_4(\text{CHO})(\text{OH}) + 3\text{NaCl} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O}$$
The reactive intermediate is dichlorocarbene ($:\text{CCl}_2$), formed from chloroform and NaOH, which attacks the ortho position of the phenoxide ion.

questions.question:
Explain briefly:

(a) Carbylamine reaction

(b) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis
questions.correctAnswer: (a) Primary amines react with CHCl₃ and alcoholic KOH to give foul-smelling isocyanides (carbylamines). Used to distinguish primary amines from secondary and tertiary amines. (b) A method to prepare pure primary aliphatic amines using phthalimide treated with KOH, then alkyl halide, followed by hydrolysis.
questions.solution:
(a) The carbylamine reaction (also called the isocyanide test) involves the reaction of a **primary amine** (aliphatic or aromatic) with chloroform ($\text{CHCl}_3$) and alcoholic potassium hydroxide ($\text{KOH}$) to give an isocyanide (carbylamine), which has an extremely unpleasant odour:
$$\text{R-NH}_2 + \text{CHCl}_3 + 3\text{KOH}(\text{alc.}) \rightarrow \text{R-NC} + 3\text{KCl} + 3\text{H}_2\text{O}$$
This reaction is used as a test to distinguish primary amines from secondary and tertiary amines, as only primary amines give a positive carbylamine test.

(b) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is a method for the preparation of **primary aliphatic amines** free from secondary and tertiary amines.

**Steps:**
1. Phthalimide is treated with alcoholic KOH to form potassium phthalimide:
$$\text{Phthalimide} + \text{KOH} \rightarrow \text{Potassium phthalimide} + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$
2. Potassium phthalimide reacts with an alkyl halide ($\text{R-X}$) via $S_N2$ reaction to give N-alkylphthalimide:
$$\text{Potassium phthalimide} + \text{R-X} \rightarrow \text{N-alkylphthalimide} + \text{KX}$$
3. N-alkylphthalimide is hydrolysed with dilute acid or alkali (or hydrazine) to yield the primary amine:
$$\text{N-alkylphthalimide} + \text{H}_2\text{O}/\text{H}^+ \rightarrow \text{R-NH}_2 + \text{Phthalic acid}$$

This method cannot be used to prepare aromatic primary amines because aryl halides do not undergo $S_N2$ reactions.

questions.question:
(a) Write chemical reactions to show that the open structure of D-glucose contains the straight chain.

(b) What type of linkage is responsible for the formation of protein?
questions.correctAnswer: (a) Reactions include: reaction with HCN (shows aldehyde group), reaction with NH₂OH (forms oxime), acylation with acetic anhydride (gives glucose pentaacetate confirming 5 OH groups), and oxidation with Br₂/H₂O (gives gluconic acid confirming aldehyde). (b) Peptide linkage ($-\text{CO-NH}-$) formed by condensation of $-\text{COOH}$ and $-\text{NH}_2$ groups of amino acids.
questions.solution:
(a) The straight-chain (open) structure of D-glucose is confirmed by the following reactions:

**Reaction with hydroxylamine ($\text{NH}_2\text{OH}$):**
$$\text{D-Glucose} + \text{NH}_2\text{OH} \rightarrow \text{Glucose oxime} + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$
This confirms the presence of the aldehyde (or carbonyl) group.

**Acylation:** Glucose reacts with acetic anhydride to give glucose pentaacetate, confirming the presence of five $-\text{OH}$ groups in the straight chain.

**Oxidation with Br₂ water:** Glucose is oxidised to gluconic acid, confirming the presence of an aldehyde group:
$$\text{D-Glucose} + \text{Br}_2/\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{Gluconic acid}$$

**Reaction with HCN:** Glucose reacts with HCN showing the presence of an aldehyde group at one end and establishes the chain structure.

These reactions collectively confirm the open straight-chain structure of D-glucose.

(b) **Peptide linkage** (also called amide bond or peptide bond) is responsible for the formation of proteins. It is formed by the condensation reaction between the $-\text{COOH}$ (carboxyl) group of one amino acid and the $-\text{NH}_2$ (amino) group of another amino acid, with the elimination of a water molecule:
$$-\text{COOH} + \text{H}_2\text{N}- \rightarrow -\text{CO-NH}- + \text{H}_2\text{O}$$
The resulting $-\text{CO-NH}-$ bond is the peptide linkage. Proteins are polypeptides made up of many amino acid units linked by these peptide bonds.

questions.question:
How will you carry out the following conversions: (Any two)

(i) Propanal to Propane

(ii) Ethanol to But-2-enal

(iii) Ethanoic acid to Ethanamide
questions.correctAnswer:
Any two of the following conversions:
(i) Propanal to Propane
(ii) Ethanol to But-2-enal
(iii) Ethanoic acid to Ethanamide
questions.solution:
(i) Propanal to Propane:
- Reagent: $LiAlH_4$ (Lithium aluminium hydride) or $H_2$ and Ni catalyst
- Reaction: $$CH_3CH_2CHO + 4[H] \rightarrow CH_3CH_2CH_3 + H_2O$$
- Mechanism: Reduction of aldehyde to alkane

(ii) Ethanol to But-2-enal:
- Reagent: PCC (Pyridinium chlorochromate) followed by aldol condensation
- Step 1: $$C_2H_5OH + [O] \rightarrow CH_3CHO \quad \text{(ethanal)}$$
- Step 2: $$2CH_3CHO \xrightarrow{NaOH} CH_3CH(OH)CH_2CHO \rightarrow CH_3CH=CHCHO + H_2O \quad \text{(But-2-enal)}$$
- Mechanism: Oxidation of ethanol to ethanal, followed by aldol condensation

(iii) Ethanoic acid to Ethanamide:
- Reagent: $NH_3$ (Ammonia)
- Reaction: $$CH_3COOH + NH_3 \rightarrow CH_3CONH_2 + H_2O$$
- Mechanism: Direct reaction of ethanoic acid with ammonia

questions.question:
In the given reaction:
$$N_2(g) + 3H_2(g) \rightarrow 2NH_3(g)$$
the rate of formation of $NH_3$ is $3.6 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$.

Calculate the

(i) Rate of reaction

(ii) Rate of disappearance of $H_2(g)$
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Rate of reaction = $1.8 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$
(ii) Rate of disappearance of $H_2$ = $5.4 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$
questions.solution:
(i) Rate of reaction:
For the reaction: $N_2(g) + 3H_2(g) \rightarrow 2NH_3(g)$
$$\text{Rate of reaction} = \left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \times \text{Rate of formation of } NH_3$$
$$= \left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \times 3.6 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$$
$$= 1.8 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$$

(ii) Rate of disappearance of $H_2$:
According to the stoichiometry of the reaction, 3 moles of $H_2$ are consumed for every 2 moles of $NH_3$ formed.
$$\text{Rate of disappearance of } H_2 = \left(\frac{3}{2}\right) \times \text{Rate of formation of } NH_3$$
$$= \left(\frac{3}{2}\right) \times 3.6 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$$
$$= 5.4 \times 10^{-4}\ mol\ L^{-1}s^{-1}$$

questions.question:
(i) State Kohlrausch's law of independent migration of ions.

(ii) Calculate the degree of dissociation $(\alpha)$ of $CH_3COOH$ if $\Lambda_m$ and $\Lambda_m^\circ$ of $CH_3COOH$ are $48\ S\ cm^2\ mol^{-1}$ and $400\ S\ cm^2\ mol^{-1}$ respectively.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) At infinite dilution, each ion contributes independently to the total molar conductivity.
(ii) $\alpha = 0.12$
questions.solution:
(i) Kohlrausch's law of independent migration of ions:
Kohlrausch's law states that at infinite dilution, each ion contributes independently to the total molar conductivity of the electrolyte. The law can be mathematically expressed as:
$$\Lambda_m^\infty = \lambda^+ + \lambda^-$$
where $\Lambda_m^\infty$ is the molar conductivity at infinite dilution, and $\lambda^+$ and $\lambda^-$ are the ionic conductivities of the cation and anion respectively at infinite dilution.

(ii) Degree of dissociation $(\alpha)$:
The degree of dissociation $(\alpha)$ can be calculated using the relation:
$$\alpha = \frac{\Lambda_m}{\Lambda_m^\infty}$$
Given: $\Lambda_m = 48\ S\ cm^2\ mol^{-1}$ and $\Lambda_m^\infty = 400\ S\ cm^2\ mol^{-1}$
$$\alpha = \frac{48}{400} = 0.12$$

questions.question:
Define the following terms:
(A) Tranquilizers
(B) Antiseptic
questions.correctAnswer:
(A) Tranquilizers are chemical compounds used for the treatment of stress, anxiety, and mental diseases by acting on the CNS.
(B) Antiseptics are substances that inhibit the growth of or destroy microorganisms when applied to living tissues.
questions.solution:
(A) Tranquilizers are a class of chemical compounds (drugs) used for the treatment of stress, anxiety, mild or severe mental diseases. They act on the central nervous system to calm the patient without causing loss of consciousness. Examples include barbiturates (e.g., phenobarbitone), benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam/valium), and meprobamate.

(B) An antiseptic is a substance that either inhibits the growth of or destroys microorganisms (bacteria, fungi, viruses) when applied to living tissues such as wounds, cuts, and skin. Some antiseptics are bactericidal (kill microbes) while others are bacteriostatic (inhibit growth). Examples include dilute solutions of dettol, boric acid, iodoform (CHI₃), and hydrogen peroxide.

alternativeQuestion.question: Explain the cleansing action of soaps.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: Soaps cleanse through micelle formation — hydrophobic tails embed in dirt/grease and hydrophilic heads face water, forming micelles that are washed away.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
The cleansing action of soaps is based on the dual nature of soap molecules — each molecule has:
- A hydrophilic (water-loving) head — the ionic carboxylate end ($-\text{COO}^-\text{Na}^+$)
- A hydrophobic (water-repelling) tail — the long hydrocarbon chain

Mechanism:
1. When soap is added to dirty water, the hydrophobic tails of soap molecules embed themselves into the oily/greasy dirt, while the hydrophilic heads remain directed outward toward the water.
2. This arrangement forms spherical clusters called micelles, with dirt trapped in the centre and ionic heads on the outer surface.
3. These micelles remain dispersed in water (forming a colloidal solution) because the negatively charged outer surface prevents them from coalescing.
4. When rinsed, the dirt-containing micelles are washed away with water, leaving the surface clean.

Soaps also lower the surface tension of water, allowing better wetting of the surface.

questions.question: For 5% solution of urea (Molar mass = 60 g/mol), calculate the osmotic pressure at 300 K. $\left[R = 0.0821 \text{ L atm K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\right]$
questions.correctAnswer: $\pi \approx 20.44 \text{ atm}$
questions.solution:
A 5% solution of urea means 5 g of urea is present in 100 mL of solution.

Given:
- $w = 5 \text{ g}$, $M = 60 \text{ g/mol}$, $V = 100 \text{ mL} = 0.1 \text{ L}$, $T = 300 \text{ K}$

Step 1: Calculate molarity (concentration):

$$C = \frac{w}{M \times V(\text{in L})} = \frac{5}{60 \times 0.1} = \frac{5}{6} = 0.833 \text{ mol/L}$$

Step 2: Apply the van't Hoff equation for osmotic pressure:

$$\pi = CRT$$

$$\pi = 0.833 \times 0.0821 \times 300$$

$$\pi \approx 20.52 \text{ atm}$$

(The paper gives $\approx 20.44$ atm using $C \approx 0.83$)

alternativeQuestion.question: Visha took two aqueous solutions — one containing 7.5 g of urea (Molar mass = 60 g/mol) and the other containing 42.75 g of substance Z in 100 g of water, respectively. It was observed that both the solutions froze at the same temperature. Calculate the molar mass of Z.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
Since both solutions freeze at the same temperature, they have the same depression in freezing point ($\Delta T_f$), and hence the same molality.

Given:
- Mass of solvent ($w_2$) = 100 g (same for both)
- Mass of urea ($w_1$) = 7.5 g, $M_1$ (urea) = 60 g/mol
- Mass of Z ($w_3$) = 42.75 g, $M_Z$ = ?

Since molalities are equal:

$$\frac{w_1 \times 1000}{M_1 \times w_2} = \frac{w_3 \times 1000}{M_Z \times w_2}$$

Since $w_2$ is the same and cancels:

$$\frac{w_1}{M_1} = \frac{w_3}{M_Z}$$

$$M_Z = \frac{w_3 \times M_1}{w_1} = \frac{42.75 \times 60}{7.5}$$

$$M_Z = 342 \text{ g/mol}$$

(This corresponds to the molar mass of sucrose, $\text{C}_{12}\text{H}_{22}\text{O}_{11}$.)

questions.question:
Analyze the given graph, drawn between the concentration of reactant vs. time. [Graph: Concentration decreases as: 1.6 at t=0, 0.8 at t=10, 0.4 at t=20, 0.2 at t=30 — exponential decay with constant half-life of 10 time units]

(A) Predict the order of the reaction.
(B) Theoretically, can the concentration of the reactant reduce to zero after infinite time? Explain.
questions.correctAnswer: (A) First-order reaction. (B) Yes, theoretically only after infinite time.
questions.solution:
(A) From the graph, the concentration of the reactant halves at regular time intervals:

$$1.6 \xrightarrow{t=10} 0.8 \xrightarrow{t=10} 0.4 \xrightarrow{t=10} 0.2$$

The half-life is constant (= 10 time units), which is a characteristic of a first-order reaction. The concentration also decreases exponentially with time, consistent with the first-order rate law:

$$[\text{A}] = [\text{A}]_0 \cdot e^{-kt}$$

(B) For a first-order reaction:

$$[\text{A}] = [\text{A}]_0 \cdot e^{-kt}$$

For $[\text{A}] = 0$, we need $e^{-kt} = 0$, which requires:

$$-kt \rightarrow -\infty \implies t \rightarrow \infty$$

Therefore, the concentration of the reactant approaches zero asymptotically — it can only theoretically become zero after infinite time. In practice, the concentration becomes negligibly small but never exactly zero in finite time.

questions.question:
Draw the shape of the following molecules:
(A) XeOF₄
(B) BrF₃
questions.correctAnswer: (A) Square pyramidal (B) T-shaped
questions.solution:
(A) XeOF₄:
In XeOF₄, Xe has 6 electron domains (4 Xe–F bonds + 1 Xe=O bond + 1 lone pair) → octahedral electron geometry. With 1 lone pair occupying an axial position and 1 double bond to O occupying another axial position, the molecular shape is square pyramidal. Xe is at centre with 4 F atoms in a square plane, O atom above the plane (double bond), and 1 lone pair below the plane.

(B) BrF₃:
In BrF₃, Br has 7 valence electrons; 3 are used to form bonds with 3 F atoms → 2 lone pairs remain. Total electron domains = 3 bond pairs + 2 lone pairs = 5 → trigonal bipyramidal electron geometry. The 2 lone pairs occupy equatorial positions (to minimise repulsion). The 3 F atoms: 2 in equatorial and 1 in axial position → molecular shape is T-shaped. The F–Br–F bond angles are slightly less than 90° due to lone pair repulsion.

questions.question:
Give the formulae of the following compounds:
(A) Potassium tetrahydroxidozincate(II)
(B) Hexaammineplatinum(IV) chloride
questions.correctAnswer: (A) $\text{K}_2[\text{Zn(OH)}_4]$ (B) $[\text{Pt(NH}_3)_6]\text{Cl}_4$
questions.solution:
(A) Potassium tetrahydroxidozincate(II):
- Central metal: Zn in +2 oxidation state
- Ligand: OH⁻ (hydroxide), 4 ligands → tetrahydroxido
- Counter ion: K⁺, two needed to balance the −2 charge of the complex ion $[\text{Zn(OH)}_4]^{2-}$
- Formula: $\text{K}_2[\text{Zn(OH)}_4]$

(B) Hexaammineplatinum(IV) chloride:
- Central metal: Pt in +4 oxidation state
- Ligand: NH₃ (ammine), 6 ligands → hexaammine
- Counter ion: Cl⁻, four needed to balance the +4 charge of the complex ion $[\text{Pt(NH}_3)_6]^{4+}$
- Formula: $[\text{Pt(NH}_3)_6]\text{Cl}_4$

questions.question:
What happens when:
(A) Propanone is treated with methyl magnesium iodide and then hydrolyzed
(B) Benzene is treated with CH₃COCl in the presence of anhydrous AlCl₃
questions.correctAnswer: (A) tert-Butyl alcohol (2-methylpropan-2-ol) is formed. (B) Acetophenone (methyl phenyl ketone) is formed.
questions.solution:
(A) Methyl magnesium iodide (CH₃MgI) is a Grignard reagent. It acts as a nucleophile, and the carbanion (CH₃⁻) attacks the carbonyl carbon of propanone, followed by hydrolysis:

$$\underset{\text{Propanone}}{\text{CH}_3\text{–CO–CH}_3} + \text{CH}_3\text{MgI} \xrightarrow{\text{1. dry ether}} \xrightarrow{\text{2. H}_3\text{O}^+} \underset{\textit{tert}\text{-butyl alcohol}}{(\text{CH}_3)_3\text{C–OH}}$$

The Grignard reagent adds across the C=O bond to give a tertiary alcohol — 2-methylpropan-2-ol (tert-butyl alcohol).

(B) This is a Friedel–Crafts acylation reaction. AlCl₃ acts as a Lewis acid catalyst, generating the acylium ion $\text{CH}_3\text{CO}^+$, which acts as the electrophile:

$$\underset{\text{Benzene}}{\text{C}_6\text{H}_6} + \underset{\text{Acetyl chloride}}{\text{CH}_3\text{COCl}} \xrightarrow{\text{Anhydrous AlCl}_3} \underset{\text{Acetophenone}}{\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{COCH}_3} + \text{HCl}$$

questions.question:
Write the names and structures of monomers in the following polymers:
(A) Bakelite
(B) Neoprene
questions.correctAnswer: (A) Phenol ($\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{OH}$) and Formaldehyde (HCHO). (B) Chloroprene ($\text{CH}_2\text{=CCl–CH=CH}_2$).
questions.solution:
(A) Bakelite is a condensation polymer (thermosetting polymer) formed by the condensation polymerisation of phenol and formaldehyde in the presence of either an acid or base catalyst.

Monomers:
$$\underset{\text{Phenol}}{\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{OH}} \quad \text{and} \quad \underset{\text{Formaldehyde}}{\text{HCHO}}$$

(B) Neoprene is produced by the addition (free radical) polymerisation of chloroprene:

$$\underset{\text{Chloroprene (2-chlorobuta-1,3-diene)}}{\text{CH}_2\text{=CCl–CH=CH}_2} \xrightarrow{\text{polymerisation}} \underset{\text{Neoprene}}{\left[-\text{CH}_2\text{–CCl=CH–CH}_2\text{–}\right]_n}$$

questions.question:
Write balanced chemical equations for the following processes:

(i) XeF₂ undergoes hydrolysis.
(ii) MnO₂ is heated with conc. HCl.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $2XeF_2(s) + 2H_2O(l) \longrightarrow 2Xe(g) + 4HF(aq) + O_2(g)$
(ii) $4HCl + MnO_2 \longrightarrow Cl_2 + MnCl_2 + 2H_2O$
questions.solution:
(i) Hydrolysis of XeF₂:
$$2XeF_2(s) + 2H_2O(l) \longrightarrow 2Xe(g) + 4HF(aq) + O_2(g)$$

(ii) MnO₂ heated with conc. HCl:
$$4HCl + MnO_2 \longrightarrow Cl_2 + MnCl_2 + 2H_2O$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
Arrange the following in the order of the property indicated for each set:

(i) $H_2O,\ H_2S,\ H_2Se,\ H_2Te$ — increasing acidic character

(ii) $HF,\ HCl,\ HBr,\ HI$ — decreasing bond enthalpy
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(i) $H_2O < H_2S < H_2Se < H_2Te$
(ii) $HF > HCl > HBr > HI$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Increasing acidic character:
$$H_2O < H_2S < H_2Se < H_2Te$$
Acidic strength increases down the group as bond strength decreases.

(ii) Decreasing bond enthalpy:
$$HF > HCl > HBr > HI$$
Bond enthalpy decreases as atomic size and bond length increase down the group.

questions.question: State Raoult's law for a solution containing volatile components. Write two characteristics of the solution which obeys Raoult's law at all concentrations.
questions.correctAnswer: Raoult's Law: $P_1 = P_1^\circ \cdot x_1$. Characteristics: (i) $\Delta_{mix}H = 0$ (ii) $\Delta_{mix}V = 0$
questions.solution:
Raoult's Law: For a solution of two volatile liquids, the partial vapour pressure of each component is directly proportional to its mole fraction present in solution.
$$P_1 \propto x_1$$
$$P_1 = P_1^\circ \cdot x_1$$
Where $P_1$ = Partial pressure of component 1, $x_1$ = Mole fraction of component 1, $P_1^\circ$ = Vapour pressure of pure component 1.

Characteristics of an Ideal Solution (obeys Raoult's law at all concentrations):
(i) $\Delta_{mix}H = 0$ (No heat is absorbed or released on mixing)
(ii) $\Delta_{mix}V = 0$ (No change in volume on mixing)

questions.question:
For the reaction:

$$2H_2O_2 \xrightarrow{I^-,\ \text{alkaline medium}} 2H_2O + O_2$$

The proposed mechanism is:

(1) $H_2O_2 + I^- \longrightarrow H_2O + IO^-$ (slow)

(2) $H_2O_2 + IO^- \longrightarrow H_2O + I^- + O_2$ (fast)

(i) Write the rate law for the reaction.
(ii) Write the overall order of reaction.
(iii) Out of steps (1) and (2), which one is the rate determining step?
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Rate = $k[H_2O_2][I^-]$ (ii) Overall order = 2 (iii) Step (1) is the rate determining step.
questions.solution:
(i) Rate Law: The rate of reaction is determined by the slowest step (Step 1):
$$\text{Rate} = -\frac{1}{2}\frac{d[H_2O_2]}{dt} = k[H_2O_2][I^-]$$

(ii) Overall Order of Reaction:
$$\text{Rate} = k[H_2O_2][I^-]$$
Order with respect to $H_2O_2$ = 1, Order with respect to $I^-$ = 1
$$\text{Overall order} = 1 + 1 = 2$$

(iii) The slowest step is the rate determining step. Therefore, Step (1) is the rate determining step.

questions.question:
When MnO₂ is fused with KOH in the presence of KNO₃ as an oxidizing agent, it gives a dark green compound (A). Compound (A) disproportionates in acidic solution to give purple compound (B). An alkaline solution of compound (B) oxidises KI to compound (C), whereas an acidified solution of compound (B) oxidises KI to (D).

Identify (A), (B), (C), and (D).
questions.correctAnswer: (A) = $K_2MnO_4$ (Potassium manganate — dark green), (B) = $KMnO_4$ (Potassium permanganate — purple), (C) = $IO_3^-$ (Iodate ion), (D) = $I_2$ (Iodine)
questions.solution:
Formation of (A): Fusion of MnO₂ with KOH and KNO₃:
$$2MnO_2 + 4KOH + O_2 \longrightarrow 2K_2MnO_4 + 2H_2O$$
(A) = $K_2MnO_4$ (Dark Green)

Disproportionation of (A) to give (B):
$$3MnO_4^{2-} + 4H^+ \longrightarrow 2MnO_4^- + MnO_2 + 2H_2O$$
(B) = $KMnO_4$ (Purple)

In acidified solution — (B) oxidises KI to (D):
$$10I^- + 2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ \longrightarrow 2Mn^{2+} + 8H_2O + 5I_2$$
(D) = $I_2$

In alkaline solution — (B) oxidises KI to (C):
$$2MnO_4^- + H_2O + I^- \longrightarrow 2MnO_2 + 2OH^- + IO_3^-$$
(C) = $IO_3^-$

questions.question: Write the IUPAC name of the complex $[Pt(en)_2Cl_2]$. Draw structures of geometrical isomers for this complex.
questions.correctAnswer: IUPAC Name: Dichloridobis(ethane-1,2-diamine)platinum(II). The complex shows cis and trans geometrical isomers.
questions.solution:
IUPAC Name: Dichloridobis(ethane-1,2-diamine)platinum(II)

Geometrical Isomers:
- Trans isomer: Pt at centre in square planar geometry; two 'en' (ethane-1,2-diamine) ligands trans to each other; two Cl atoms trans to each other.
- Cis isomer: Pt at centre in square planar geometry; two 'en' (ethane-1,2-diamine) ligands on the same side; two Cl atoms adjacent to each other (cis).

questions.question:
Out of $[CoF_6]^{3-}$ and $[Co(en)_3]^{3+}$, which one complex is:
(i) paramagnetic
(ii) more stable
(iii) inner orbital complex
(iv) high spin complex

(Atomic no. of Co = 27)
questions.correctAnswer: (i) $[CoF_6]^{3-}$ is paramagnetic. (ii) $[Co(en)_3]^{3+}$ is more stable. (iii) $[Co(en)_3]^{3+}$ is the inner orbital complex. (iv) $[CoF_6]^{3-}$ is the high spin complex.
questions.solution:
Electronic configuration:
$$Co\ (Z=27) = 1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^7$$
$$Co^{3+} = 1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 3d^6$$

$[CoF_6]^{3-}$: F⁻ is a weak field ligand → does not cause pairing of electrons. Hybridisation: $sp^3d^2$ (outer orbital). 3d orbitals retain 4 unpaired electrons.

$[Co(en)_3]^{3+}$: en is a strong field ligand → causes pairing of electrons in 3d. Hybridisation: $d^2sp^3$ (inner orbital). All 3d electrons are paired.

(i) $[CoF_6]^{3-}$ is paramagnetic due to the presence of four unpaired electrons.
(ii) $[Co(en)_3]^{3+}$ is more stable due to the chelate effect (en is a bidentate ligand forming chelate rings).
(iii) $[Co(en)_3]^{3+}$ is the inner orbital complex ($d^2sp^3$ hybridisation using inner 3d orbitals).
(iv) $[CoF_6]^{3-}$ is the high spin complex ($sp^3d^2$ hybridisation, weak field ligand, maximum unpaired electrons).

questions.question:
Write the structures of compounds A and B in each of the following reactions:

(i) $$\text{Ethylbenzene} \xrightarrow{KMnO_4-KOH} A \xrightarrow{H_3O^+} B$$

(ii) $$\text{Cyclohexanol} \xrightarrow{CrO_3} A \xrightarrow{H_2N-NH-CONH_2} B$$
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) A = Potassium benzoate ($C_6H_5COOK$), B = Benzoic acid ($C_6H_5COOH$)
(ii) A = Cyclohexanone, B = Cyclohexanone semicarbazone
questions.solution:
(i)
$$\underset{\text{Ethylbenzene}}{C_6H_5CH_2CH_3} \xrightarrow{KMnO_4-KOH} \underset{\textbf{A}}{C_6H_5COOK} \xrightarrow{H_3O^+} \underset{\textbf{B (Benzoic acid)}}{C_6H_5COOH}$$
A = Potassium benzoate ($C_6H_5COOK$)
B = Benzoic acid ($C_6H_5COOH$)

(ii)
Cyclohexanol $\xrightarrow{CrO_3}$ Cyclohexanone (A) $\xrightarrow{H_2N-NH-CONH_2}$ Cyclohexanone semicarbazone (B)
A = Cyclohexanone (cyclic ketone with C=O)
B = Cyclohexanone semicarbazone (cyclohexane ring with $=N-NH-CONH_2$ substituent)

questions.question: Analysis shows that FeO has a non-stoichiometric composition with formula $\text{Fe}_{0.95}\text{O}$. Give reason.
questions.correctAnswer: In $\text{Fe}_{0.95}\text{O}$, some Fe²⁺ sites are replaced by Fe³⁺ ions, causing metal deficiency defect.
questions.solution: In $\text{Fe}_{0.95}\text{O}$, some Fe²⁺ sites in the crystal lattice are replaced by Fe³⁺ ions. To maintain electrical neutrality, for every 3 Fe²⁺ ions replaced by 2 Fe³⁺ ions, one cation site becomes vacant. This metal deficiency defect (a type of non-stoichiometric defect) results in a compound where the ratio of Fe to O is less than 1:1. Because it is a defect structure and not a simple interstitial compound, it does not follow a fixed stoichiometric composition.

questions.question:
Complete and balance the following chemical equations:

(a) $\text{Fe}^{2+} + \text{MnO}_4^- + \text{H}^+ \longrightarrow$

(b) $\text{MnO}_4^- + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{I}^- \longrightarrow$
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) $5\text{Fe}^{2+} + 2\text{MnO}_4^- + 8\text{H}^+ \longrightarrow 5\text{Fe}^{3+} + 2\text{Mn}^{2+} + 4\text{H}_2\text{O}$

(b) $2\text{MnO}_4^- + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{I}^- \longrightarrow 2\text{MnO}_2 + 2\text{OH}^- + \text{IO}_3^-$
questions.solution:
(a) Balanced equation:
$$5\text{Fe}^{2+} + 2\text{MnO}_4^- + 8\text{H}^+ \longrightarrow 5\text{Fe}^{3+} + 2\text{Mn}^{2+} + 4\text{H}_2\text{O}$$

(b) Balanced equation:
$$2\text{MnO}_4^- + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{I}^- \longrightarrow 2\text{MnO}_2 + 2\text{OH}^- + \text{IO}_3^-$$

questions.question:
How do you convert the following?

(a) Ethanal to Propanone

(b) Toluene to Benzoic acid
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) Ethanal → Propanone via Grignard reagent and oxidation
(b) Toluene → Benzoic acid via oxidation with K₂Cr₂O₇/H⁺
questions.solution:
(a) Ethanal to Propanone:
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{OH} \xrightarrow{\text{PCC}} \text{CH}_3\text{CHO}$$
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CHO} \xrightarrow{1.\ \text{CH}_3\text{MgBr};\ 2.\ \text{H}_3\text{O}^+} \text{CH}_3\text{CH(OH)CH}_3$$
$$\text{CH}_3\text{CH(OH)CH}_3 \xrightarrow{\text{PCC}} \text{CH}_3\text{COCH}_3\ \text{(Propanone)}$$

(b) Toluene to Benzoic acid:
$$\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{CH}_3 \xrightarrow{\text{K}_2\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7/\text{H}^+} \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{COOH}$$

alternativeQuestion.question:
Account for the following:

(a) Aromatic carboxylic acids do not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction.

(b) $\text{pK}_a$ value of 4-nitrobenzoic acid is lower than that of benzoic acid.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(a) The –COOH group deactivates the ring towards electrophilic substitution.
(b) –NO₂ group increases acidity, so pKa is lower for 4-nitrobenzoic acid.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(a) The –COOH group is a strong electron-withdrawing group that shows a –M (mesomeric) effect. It withdraws electron density from the aromatic ring, making it electron-deficient and deactivated towards electrophilic substitution reactions (such as Friedel-Crafts). Since Friedel-Crafts reaction requires an electron-rich aromatic ring, aromatic carboxylic acids do not undergo this reaction.

(b) The –NO₂ group at the para position is strongly electron-withdrawing in nature (both –I and –M effects). This withdrawing effect increases the polarity of the O–H bond in the –COOH group, making it easier to release the proton (H⁺). As acidity increases, $\text{pK}_a$ decreases. Therefore, 4-nitrobenzoic acid is a stronger acid than benzoic acid and has a lower $\text{pK}_a$ value.

questions.question:
For the reaction:

$$2\text{N}_2\text{O}_5(g) \longrightarrow 4\text{NO}_2(g) + \text{O}_2(g)$$

the rate of formation of NO₂(g) is $2.8 \times 10^{-3}\ \text{Ms}^{-1}$. Calculate the rate of disappearance of $\text{N}_2\text{O}_5(g)$.
questions.correctAnswer: Rate of disappearance of $\text{N}_2\text{O}_5 = 1.4 \times 10^{-3}\ \text{Ms}^{-1}$
questions.solution:
The rate of reaction is expressed as:
$$\text{Rate} = -\frac{1}{2}\frac{d[\text{N}_2\text{O}_5]}{dt} = \frac{1}{4}\frac{d[\text{NO}_2]}{dt} = \frac{d[\text{O}_2]}{dt}$$

Given:
$$\frac{d[\text{NO}_2]}{dt} = 2.8 \times 10^{-3}\ \text{Ms}^{-1}$$

Therefore:
$$-\frac{d[\text{N}_2\text{O}_5]}{dt} = \frac{2}{4}\frac{d[\text{NO}_2]}{dt} = \frac{1}{2} \times 2.8 \times 10^{-3}\ \text{Ms}^{-1}$$

$$-\frac{d[\text{N}_2\text{O}_5]}{dt} = 1.4 \times 10^{-3}\ \text{Ms}^{-1}$$

questions.question:
Among the hydrides of Group-15 elements, which have the:

(a) Lowest boiling point?

(b) Maximum basic character?

(c) Highest bond angle?

(d) Maximum reducing character?
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) PH₃
(b) NH₃
(c) NH₃ (107.8°)
(d) BiH₃
questions.solution:
(a) Lowest boiling point = PH₃
NH₃ has an anomalously high boiling point due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Among the rest, PH₃ has the lowest boiling point as it has the weakest van der Waals forces.

(b) Maximum basic character = NH₃
As we go down Group 15, the size of the central atom increases, lone pair becomes less available for donation (more diffuse), so basic character decreases: $\text{NH}_3 > \text{PH}_3 > \text{AsH}_3 > \text{SbH}_3 > \text{BiH}_3$.

(c) Highest bond angle = NH₃ (107.8°)
In NH₃, the N atom is small and highly electronegative, so the bonding pairs are closer to N, causing greater bp–bp repulsion and a larger bond angle compared to heavier hydrides.

(d) Maximum reducing character = BiH₃
Reducing character of hydrides increases down the group as the E–H bond strength decreases. Hence BiH₃ has the maximum reducing character.

questions.question:
(a) Arrange the following compounds in the increasing order of their acid strength:
p-Cresol, p-Nitrophenol, Phenol

(b) Write the mechanism (using curved arrow notation) of the following reaction:
$$CH_2=CH_2 \xrightarrow{H_3O^+} CH_3-CH_2^+ + H_2O$$
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) p-Cresol < Phenol < p-Nitrophenol
(b) Step 1: Protonation of ethene by H⁺ to form carbocation. Step 2: Attack of water on the carbocation. Step 3: Deprotonation to give ethanol.
questions.solution:
**(a) Increasing order of acid strength:**
$$\text{p-Cresol} < \text{Phenol} < \text{p-Nitrophenol}$$

**Reason:**
- The –NO₂ group is an electron-withdrawing group (–M effect), which withdraws electron density from the benzene ring, stabilizing the conjugate base of p-nitrophenol. Higher stability of conjugate base → higher acidity.
- In the case of p-cresol, the +I effect of the methyl group destabilizes the conjugate base, making it the weakest acid.

**(b) Mechanism of the reaction:**
$$CH_2=CH_2 + H^{\oplus} \longrightarrow CH_3-\overset{\oplus}{C}H_2$$
$$CH_3-\overset{\oplus}{C}H_2 + H_2O \longrightarrow CH_3-CH_2-\overset{\oplus}{O}H_2 \xrightarrow{-H^{\oplus}} CH_3-CH_2-\ddot{O}-H$$

Step 1: Protonation of ethene by H⁺ to form carbocation.
Step 2: Attack of water (nucleophile) on the carbocation.
Step 3: Deprotonation to give ethanol.

alternativeQuestion.question:
Write the structures of the products when Butan-2-ol reacts with the following:
(a) CrO₃
(b) SOCl₂
alternativeQuestion.solution:
**(a) Reaction of Butan-2-ol with CrO₃:**
$$CH_3-CH_2-\underset{|}{C}H-CH_3 + CrO_3 \longrightarrow CH_3-CH_2-\overset{\|}{C}-CH_3$$
$$\quad\quad\quad\quad OH \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad O$$
$$\text{2-Butanol} \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \text{Butan-2-one}$$
CrO₃ oxidizes the secondary alcohol (butan-2-ol) to the corresponding ketone (butan-2-one).

**(b) Reaction of Butan-2-ol with SOCl₂:**
$$CH_3-CH_2-\underset{|}{C}H-CH_3 + SOCl_2 \longrightarrow CH_3-CH_2-\underset{|}{C}H-CH_3 + SO_2 + HCl$$
$$\quad\quad\quad\quad OH \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad Cl$$
$$\text{2-Butanol}\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \text{2-Chlorobutane}$$
SOCl₂ replaces the –OH group with –Cl to give 2-Chlorobutane.

questions.question:
Calculate the number of unit cells in 8.1 g of aluminum if it crystallizes in a face-centered cubic (f.c.c.) structure.
(Atomic mass of Al = 27 g mol⁻¹)
questions.correctAnswer: $0.075 \times N_A$ unit cells
questions.solution:
Moles of aluminum:
$$n_{Al} = \frac{\text{Mass}}{\text{Molar Mass}} = \frac{8.1}{27} = 0.3 \text{ moles}$$

In an f.c.c. unit cell, the number of atoms per unit cell = **4**

Therefore:
- 4 atoms are found in 1 unit cell
- 1 atom is found in $\frac{1}{4}$ unit cell
- $N_A$ atoms (1 mole) are found in $\frac{N_A}{4}$ unit cells

For 0.3 moles of Al:
$$\text{Number of unit cells} = \frac{N_A}{4} \times 0.3 = 0.075 \times N_A$$

questions.question:
Draw the structures of the following:
(a) H₂SO₃
(b) HClO₃
questions.correctAnswer:
(a) H₂SO₃: Central S atom with one S=O bond, two S–OH bonds, and one lone pair on S.
(b) HClO₃: Central Cl atom with two Cl=O bonds, one –O–H bond, and one lone pair on Cl.
questions.solution:
**(a) H₂SO₃ (Sulphurous acid):**
Structure: S atom with one $S=O$ bond and two $S-OH$ bonds, plus one lone pair on S.
The sulfur is in +4 oxidation state.

**(b) HClO₃ (Chloric acid):**
Structure: Cl atom bonded to two $Cl=O$ groups and one $-O-H$ group, with one lone pair on Cl.
The chlorine is in +5 oxidation state.

questions.question: Write the name of the cell which is generally used in hearing aids. Write the reactions taking place at the anode and the cathode of this cell.
questions.correctAnswer:
Mercury Cell.
Anode: $Zn(Hg) + 2OH^{\ominus} \longrightarrow ZnO(s) + H_2O + 2e^{\ominus}$
Cathode: $HgO + H_2O + 2e^{\ominus} \longrightarrow Hg(l) + 2OH^{\ominus}$
questions.solution:
The **Mercury cell** is used in hearing aids. It consists of:
- **Anode:** Zinc–mercury amalgam (Zn–Hg)
- **Cathode:** A paste of HgO and carbon

**Reactions at the electrodes:**

**Anode (oxidation):**
$$Zn(Hg) + 2OH^{\ominus} \longrightarrow ZnO(s) + H_2O + 2e^{\ominus}$$

**Cathode (reduction):**
$$HgO + H_2O + 2e^{\ominus} \longrightarrow Hg(l) + 2OH^{\ominus}$$

questions.question:
Using IUPAC norms write the formulae for the following:
(a) Sodium dicyanidoaurate (I)
(b) Tetraammine chloridonitrito-N-platinum (IV) sulphate
questions.solution:
**(a) Sodium dicyanidoaurate (I):**
$$Na[Au(CN)_2]$$
Sodium is the cation; gold(I) with two cyano ligands forms the anionic complex.

**(b) Tetraammine chloridonitrito-N-platinum (IV) sulphate:**
$$[Pt(NH_3)_4Cl(NO_2)](SO_4)_2$$
Platinum(IV) is the central metal ion; the complex cation contains four ammonia ligands, one chlorido ligand, and one nitrito-N ligand; sulphate is the counter anion. Since Pt is +4 and the complex ion has a net +2 charge, two sulphate ions balance the charge.

questions.question:
(i) Gas (A) is more soluble in water than Gas (B) at the same temperature. Which one of the two gases will have the higher value of $K_H$ (Henry's constant) and why?

(ii) In a non-ideal solution, what type of deviation shows the formation of maximum boiling azeotropes?
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Gas B will have the higher value of K_H. (ii) Negative deviation from Raoult's law leads to the formation of maximum boiling azeotropes.
questions.solution:
(i) According to Henry's law: p = K_H · x, where p is the partial pressure of the gas and x is the mole fraction of the gas dissolved. A higher K_H corresponds to lower solubility. Since Gas B is less soluble than Gas A, Gas B has the higher K_H.

(ii) When intermolecular interactions between unlike molecules (A–B) are stronger than those between like molecules (A–A or B–B), the solution shows negative deviation from Raoult's law. This results in a lower vapour pressure than ideal, causing the mixture to have a higher boiling point than either pure component, forming a maximum boiling azeotrope.

questions.question:
Write the structure of the following:
(i) BrF₃
(ii) XeF₄
questions.correctAnswer: (i) BrF₃: T-shaped geometry with 2 lone pairs in equatorial positions and 3 F atoms (sp³d hybridisation). (ii) XeF₄: Square planar geometry with 2 lone pairs in axial positions (sp³d² hybridisation).
questions.solution:
(i) BrF₃ has 5 electron pairs around Br (3 bond pairs + 2 lone pairs) → sp³d hybridisation → T-shaped molecular geometry with two lone pairs in equatorial positions.

(ii) XeF₄ has 6 electron pairs around Xe (4 bond pairs + 2 lone pairs) → sp³d² hybridisation → Square planar molecular geometry with lone pairs in axial positions.

alternativeQuestion.question:
What happens when:
(i) SO₂ gas is passed through an aqueous solution of Fe³⁺ salt.
(ii) XeF₄ reacts with SbF₅.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer: (i) SO₂ reduces Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺; the brown colour turns green. (ii) [XeF₃]⁺[SbF₆]⁻ is formed.
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) SO₂ acts as a reducing agent, reducing Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺. Reaction: 2Fe³⁺ + SO₂ + 2H₂O → 2Fe²⁺ + SO₄²⁻ + 4H⁺. The brown colour of the iron(III) solution turns green.

(ii) XeF₄ donates F⁻ to the strong Lewis acid SbF₅, forming the ionic complex [XeF₃]⁺[SbF₆]⁻. Reaction: XeF₄ + SbF₅ → [XeF₃]⁺ + [SbF₆]⁻.

questions.question:
When a coordination compound CoCl₃·6NH₃ is mixed with AgNO₃, 3 moles of AgCl are precipitated per mole of the compound. Write:
(i) Structural formula of the complex.
(ii) IUPAC name of the complex.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) [Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃ (ii) Hexaamminecobalt(III) chloride
questions.solution: Since 3 moles of AgCl are precipitated, all 3 Cl⁻ ions are outside the coordination sphere (as free ions). The central metal Co is in +3 oxidation state, coordinated to 6 NH₃ ligands. Hence the formula is [Co(NH₃)₆]Cl₃ and IUPAC name is Hexaamminecobalt(III) chloride.

questions.question:
For a reaction: $\text{H}_2 + \text{Cl}_2 \xrightarrow{h\nu} 2\text{HCl}$, Rate $= K$

(i) Write the order and molecularity of this reaction.
(ii) Write the unit of $K$.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Order: Zero (0); Molecularity: 2 (bimolecular). (ii) Unit of K: mol L⁻¹ s⁻¹
questions.solution:
(i) Since Rate = K (independent of concentration of reactants), the reaction is zero order. Molecularity refers to the number of reacting species in the elementary step, which is 2 (one molecule of H₂ and one molecule of Cl₂), hence molecularity = 2.

(ii) For a zero-order reaction: Rate = K. Unit of K = Unit of Rate = mol L⁻¹ s⁻¹.

questions.question:
Write the chemical equations involved in the following reactions:
(i) Hoffmann-bromamide degradation reaction
(ii) Carbylamine reaction
questions.correctAnswer: (i) R-CO-NH₂ + Br₂ + 4NaOH → R-NH₂ + Na₂CO₃ + 2NaBr + 2H₂O (ii) R-NH₂ + CHCl₃ + 3KOH → R-NC + 3KCl + 3H₂O
questions.solution:
(i) In the Hoffmann bromamide degradation, a primary amide reacts with bromine in the presence of strong base (NaOH) to yield a primary amine with one fewer carbon atom than the original amide. The carbonyl carbon is lost as carbonate. Equation: Ar/R-CO-NH₂ + Br₂ + 4NaOH → Ar/R-NH₂ + Na₂CO₃ + 2NaBr + 2H₂O.

(ii) When a primary amine is heated with chloroform and alcoholic KOH, a foul-smelling isocyanide (carbylamine) is produced. This reaction is used as a test for primary amines. Equation: Ar/R-NH₂ + CHCl₃ + 3KOH → Ar/R-NC + 3KCl + 3H₂O.

questions.question:
Write the IUPAC name of the given compound:

questions.correctAnswer: 2,2-Dimethylpropan-1-ol
questions.solution: The compound $CH_3 - C(CH_3)_2 - CH_2 - OH$ has a 3-carbon main chain with two methyl substituents at carbon 2 and a hydroxyl group at carbon 1. IUPAC name: 2,2-Dimethylpropan-1-ol.

questions.question: Why do transition elements show variable oxidation states? How is the variability in oxidation states of d-block different from that of the p-block elements?
questions.correctAnswer: Transition elements show variable oxidation states because of small energy difference between 3d and 4s orbitals. d-block elements show only positive oxidation states, while p-block elements show both positive and negative oxidation states.
questions.solution:
**Variable Oxidation States in Transition Elements:**
Transition elements show variable oxidation states because there is a small energy difference between the 3d and 4s orbitals. Therefore, both 3d and 4s electrons participate in bond formation, leading to variable oxidation states.

**Difference from p-block elements:**
- p-block elements show both positive and negative oxidation states.
- d-block (transition) elements show only positive oxidation states.

questions.question:
Calculate the time to deposit 1.5 g of silver at cathode when a current of 1.5 A was passed through the solution of AgNO₃.
(Molar mass of Ag $= 108\ g\ mol^{-1}$, $1\ F = 96500\ C\ mol^{-1}$)
questions.solution:
$$Ag^+ + e^- \longrightarrow Ag(s)$$

$\because$ 108 g of Ag requires $= 96500\ C$

$\therefore$ 1.5 g of Ag requires:
$$= \frac{96500}{108} \times 1.5 = 1340.2\ C$$

Using $t = \dfrac{Q}{i}$:
$$t = \frac{1340.2}{1.5} = 893.5 \text{ sec}$$

questions.question:
Write the reagents used in the following reactions:

(i) $C_6H_5 - CO - CH_3 \xrightarrow{?} C_6H_5 - CH_2 - CH_3$

(ii) $CH_3 - COOH \xrightarrow{?} CH_3 - COCl$
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $Zn\text{-}Hg\ /\ HCl$ (Clemmensen reduction)
(ii) $PCl_5$
questions.solution:
(i) Reagent: $Zn\text{-}Hg\ /\ HCl$ — This is Clemmensen reduction which converts a carbonyl group to a methylene group.

(ii) Reagent: $PCl_5$ — Phosphorus pentachloride converts carboxylic acid to acid chloride.

alternativeQuestion.question:
Arrange the following compounds in increasing order of their property as indicated:

(i) $CH_3CHO,\ C_6H_5CHO,\ HCHO$
(Reactivity towards nucleophilic addition reaction)

(ii) 2,4-dinitrobenzoic acid, 4-methoxybenzoic acid, 4-nitrobenzoic acid
(Acidic character)
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Increasing order of reactivity towards nucleophilic addition:
$$C_6H_5CHO < CH_3CHO < HCHO$$
HCHO is most reactive due to absence of alkyl/aryl groups. Benzaldehyde is least reactive due to resonance stabilisation of the carbonyl group.

(ii) Increasing order of acidic character:
$$\text{4-methoxybenzoic acid} < \text{4-nitrobenzoic acid} < \text{2,4-dinitrobenzoic acid}$$
Electron-withdrawing groups ($-NO_2$) increase acidic character; electron-donating groups ($-OCH_3$) decrease acidic character.

questions.question:
(i) Why are aquatic species more comfortable in cold water than in warm water?

(ii) What happens when we place the blood cell in saline water solution (hypertonic solution)? Give reason.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Because the dissolution of $O_2$ is greater in cold water.
(ii) The blood cell will shrink (crenation/plasmolysis) because water moves out of the cell through osmosis.
questions.solution:
(i) Aquatic species are more comfortable in cold water than in warm water because the dissolution of $O_2$ is greater in cold water. The dissolution of gases is an exothermic process; at lower temperatures, gases dissolve more in water (Le Chatelier's principle).

(ii) The blood cell will shrink (crenation/plasmolysis).
Reason: In a hypertonic saline solution, the concentration outside the cell is higher than inside. Water moves out of the cell through osmosis, causing it to shrink.

questions.question:
(i) Name the method used for the refining of titanium.

(ii) What is the role of Zn in the extraction of silver?

(iii) Reduction of metal oxide to metal becomes easier if the metal obtained is in liquid state. Why?
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Van Arkel method
(ii) Zinc displaces silver from its complex salt solution
(iii) Because $\Delta S = +ve$ (entropy increases), making $\Delta G$ more negative
questions.solution:
(i) Van Arkel method is used for refining of titanium.

(ii) Zinc displaces silver from its complex salt solution:
$$2[Ag(CN)_2]^- + Zn \longrightarrow [Zn(CN)_4]^{2-} + 2Ag_{(s)}$$

(iii) When the metal is obtained in the liquid state, $\Delta S = +ve$ (entropy increases), which makes $\Delta G$ more negative, thus making the reduction easier.

questions.question:
(i) $E^0$ value for the $Mn^{3+}/Mn^{2+}$ couple is positive $(+1.5\ V)$ whereas that of $Cr^{3+}/Cr^{2+}$ is negative $(-0.4\ V)$. Why?

(ii) Transition metals form coloured compounds. Why?

(iii) Complete the following equation:
$$2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ + 5C_2O_4^{2-} \rightarrow$$
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $Mn^{3+} \rightarrow Mn^{2+}$ is favoured due to stable half-filled $d^5$ configuration; $Cr^{3+}$ is more stable than $Cr^{2+}$ due to stable $t_{2g}^3$ configuration.
(ii) Due to d-d transitions when visible light is absorbed.
(iii) $2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ + 5C_2O_4^{2-} \longrightarrow 10CO_2 + 8H_2O + 2Mn^{2+}$
questions.solution:
(i) The $Mn^{3+}/Mn^{2+}$ couple is positive because $Mn^{3+} \rightarrow Mn^{2+}$ is favoured due to the stable half-filled ($d^5$) electronic configuration of $Mn^{2+}$, giving it reduction tendency. $Cr^{2+} \rightarrow Cr^{3+}$ shows oxidation tendency. $Cr^{3+}$ is more stable than $Cr^{2+}$ due to the stable $t_{2g}^3$ electronic configuration.

(ii) Transition metals form coloured compounds due to d-d transitions. When visible light falls on these compounds, electrons absorb energy and transition between d-orbitals of different energy levels, emitting the complementary colour.

(iii) $$2MnO_4^- + 16H^+ + 5C_2O_4^{2-} \longrightarrow 10CO_2 + 8H_2O + 2Mn^{2+}$$
